Brita contains activated carbon which adsorbs a bunch of different organic molecules. Distillation extracts volatile compounds that boil at low temperatures first, so those actually come through along with the water, but salts and minerals will be left behind. A bunch of the volatile compounds that come through the distiller first are also organic compounds that the carbon filter will remove, so that's why the Dr. Pepper results seemed to be opposites. You could get better filtration by combining these methods since they have particularly different strengths and weaknesses.

The process of distilling functions in stages. When you take something with multiple boiling points, the lowest BP will be the most concentrated. In alcohol, the lower BP is ethanol, so you concentrate it with higher alcohol and less water. The reason some flavors, like the amaretto, were so strong is because they are volatile oils that convert to vapors much more readily than the surrounding water. Likewise, you lose 90-98% of coloration in things since dyes and coloring are often higher BP or made of dissolved solids.

Amaretto flavor is largely caused by benzaldehyde, a chemical that is present in both almonds and cherries. As a result it smells and tastes like an exact middle ground between an almond and cherry. In fact bitter almond oil is almost 100% pure benzaldehyde.

Can you distil Dr. Pepper? Well, you would know if you tried. This was not a great attempt at all, distillation of anything other than water does not work like this... That device is only suited for distilling water from the tap. If you have other additives that possibly boil below 100c (like flavours and aromas) then they will also evaporate into your 'clean' sample. Ethers and terpenes that make flavours evaporate at a lower temperature than water so you will always get these out first. To combat this you have to discard your first small glass of water from the output and then the rest should be cleaner. Ultimately you need the correct apparatus, a fractal distillation set up with a heating mantle that has been run through the appropriate cycles with the correct temperatures can separate everything and leave you with clean water. BUT, this would cost into the $150-200+ region to get set up with though.

The main reason the distiller has off flavors is the flavorings boiling point is lower than that of water or the distiller is too hot itself. If you were to take a thermometer and watch the temp inside the distiller you will probably notice the temp rises to a point, liquid will start coming over then the temp will rise again and more liquid will distill. At every pause in the temperature a different substance is being distilled for instance water/alcohol. Water is 100c for boiling temp alcohol is 82c than that. If you put the water/alcohol into a distiller the temp will rise to 82c the mixture will boil and the alcohol will distill over once a large portion of the alcohol is gone then the temp slowly rises toward the 100c mark and the actual water starts boiling and you will get water through the distiller instead of alcohol, and that's the basics of moonshine.

With the distiller it really depends on the boiling point of the chemicals in the liquid.  Anything that boils at a lower temperature than water (or whatever temp setting on the machine) will also boil off with the water.  Alcohol boils at a much lower temperature for example and will be some of the first run off you get.  The machine probably runs hotter than the boiling temp of water. Dissolved minerals will increase the boiling temperature, so as the water boils off the temperature of the remaining liquid will increase and other things will reach their boiling temperatures which is why the water from the Dr Pepper changed flavors after the initial water boiled away.

The last experiment with the salt: the regular filter wouldn't have ever worked because unlike the superior one, it doesn't heat up the liquid. Salt dissolves in liquid, so evaporaring the liquid and then condescending it is the only way to seperate the solvent from the liquid. I can't explain the colour change, but that was a consistent feature so and may be to do with the base liquid having "kept" the colour while the evaporated and condensed water was clear, but otherwise, the regular filter lacked the heating element to seperate a salt solution

It's pretty logical, some of the tastes in fruits are water soluable, and have a lower boiling point. When you try to distill the water, those things with a lower boiling point will distill first (very clear with the dr pepper example, which first gives very strong almond flavor, but then less flavored water). So you can only distill the water completely if all other ingredients have a higher boiling point

Distilling does not actually make water pure.  There are often impurities that have similar boiling points to water that will actually make it over to the finished product.  Really the only way to get completely pure water is reverse osmosis.  And it's important to note that drinking a large amount of distilled or R.O. water is not great for you.  It can seriously affect your electrolyte balance and lead to water intoxication or even death.

This video again showed what happens when you boil aromatic compounds. The boiling point of aromatic compounds are less then water (alcohol is also in this category), so they will still be present in the vapor and will condense. That's why you get a tree like taste after boiling apple juice. On the other hand brita removes the aromatic compounds better, they just get stuck in the filter. For salt: the boiling point of salt is much much higher than water so when boiling you get rid of it completely. On the other hand brita doesn't do much to salt water, as the molecules of salt just pass through the filter. What I would like to see is a combination of both methods. Boiled brita filtered apple juice will probably taste much more like clean water.
